I cold-applied to 150 internships as a freshman with no referrals and no work experience. Yet, I still managed to land 8 first-round interviews and 3 offers for paid summer internships. I feel like this is sort of a hot take with all of the content on LinkedIn focused around networking [and getting referrals], but like it or not, you still have to have a strong resume to get your foot in the door. More and more companies are putting less and less weight on referrals in an effort to create a more equal playing field, and some companies don't accept referrals for internships AT ALL. So what can you do to better your chances in a sea of ultra-competitive applicants? Make your resume so compelling that the hiring manager has no choice but to give you a shot! One of the best ways to do that is the Google X-Y-Z method. This method is not new or novel; lots of people, especially on LinkedIn, have mentioned or discussed it. But not a lot of people explain exactly how to implement it. So here's how to implement the Google XYZ resume method + real examples I've used! If you want to learn even more about how to craft a compelling resume, I still have 5 spots left open in my 2-hour resume writing masterclass, happening TOMORROW. Reserve your spot here [if the time doesn't work for your schedule, no worries! Register for the class and you'll be sent a recording of the whole class!] The Google XYZ Method: Accomplished [X] as measured by [Y], by doing [Z]. Now let's break it down ~ [X] Start with a past-tense action verb that's appropriate for the experience ex. Achieved, Improved, Launched, Transformed, Designed, Built, etc. [X] Name the task at hand ~ designed a web-based innovation management platfor (design example), built a native iOS mobile application that connected the user (engineering example), led a team to deliver a prototype and pitch deck to define a minimum viable product (product example). [Y] Quantify the impact your accomplishment had ~ ...thereby saving ET $49,000/year on software outsourcing (cost impact), ...pilot for 300+ participants, (customer impact), ...resulted in $8.7k in sales (revenue impact). [Z] Elaborate on how you did the task and what skills it took to do it ~ ...[in order] to define a minimum viable product, demonstrate user flows, and outline product KPIs (product example), to test the efficacy of process by evaluating a previously-identified efficiency opportunity against the process (process engineering example). breakdown of the 5 key elements of my resume & why each one is so important

I wrote a resume that got me SWE intern interviews at TikTok, Accenture, Ford, Analog Devices (ADI), SiriusXM, three offers from startups and offers from Medidata [a Fortune Future 50], SAP, and Disney as a freshman. Here is a breakdown of the 5 key elements of my resume & why each one is so important: Header - email, phone number, LinkedIn link, GitHub link, and portfolio website link. Include your contact info since the hiring team needs to know how to contact you. Include your LinkedIn, GitHub, and portfolio to give the hiring team a comprehensive look at who you are and what makes you perfect for the job. Education - relevant coursework and activities/organizations. Some internships, like Microsoft Explore, require a certain level of coursework (ex. Calculus I, Intro to CS). Other companies may expect you to have completed higher-level coursework, like DSA. Showing involvement in on-campus organizations can show off non-work interests or your dedication to a specific niche (ex. Cybersecurity, Product). Skills - professional skills, software, and programming languages. Almost any job requires you to have the first two, and most tech jobs require all three. Professional skills generally refer to industry- or role-related skills (ex. project management), and software skills refer to software tools you know how to use (ex. Asana, Jira, Confluence). Technical Experience - Notice that I didn't say work experience ~ that's because I didn't have any. I made do with what I had which was my experience at Berkeley's PUF Immersion program, Girls Who Code's SIP, and Kode with Klossy's Web Dev camp. I didn't necessarily have work experience, but I demonstrated both knowledge and applied experience in the area I was trying to break into (SWE). Projects ~ saved the best for last! Projects are not only a way to show off your technical skills but also to show initiative in doing things outside of academics. Two of my projects from my freshman year were an iOS mobile app and a hackathon project that got 2nd place. Want to write a killer resume that gets you offers like mine did? I did my first startup pitch competition & I got 2nd place!!

About a week ago, I made a very last-minute decision to enter the 1st annual LaunchNevada Pitch Competition. Yesterday, I was SO nervous . My stomach was in knots for hours beforehand, and I couldn't even get my heart rate down until right before it was my turn to pitch. Nerves aside, I still gave a pitch that I'm pretty proud of and was good enough to get 2nd place (+a $1,000 prize). I watched all of the other pitches, and based on those + mine, here are a few key tips/observations to win/place at a pitch competition: Keep your presentation on time! If you go over your given time limit, it looks like you didn't rehearse, and makes you look unprepared. Plus, there is nothing worse/more embarrassing than getting hard-stopped by the judges halfway through your slides. Keep your deck small. You should be able to convey your concept in <10 slides. The best pitches are typically around 5-6 slides. A good rule of thumb is to make your deck 1/2 as many slides as you have minutes [10 minutes = 5 slides]. 3 Observe other pitches if you can. You can't always control the order in which you go; I went 10th out of 11 last night, and that was by luck of the draw [literally, we drew numbers]. But if you pay attention to the other pitches, you can learn from their mistakes and even pre-empt the types of questions the judges might ask. 4 BFFR ~ Be realistic w/ your numbers [market size, projections, etc.]. No judge wants to see that you have an idea for a local coffee shop and claim to have a $150B total addressable market. In addition, no judge wants to see you have $10M revenue projections in your first year when you don't even have a flushed-out product. The Q&A is everything. TBH, I think pitch competition scoring is heavily influenced by how the pitcher handles the Q&A. The judges will ask about things that you didn't cover in your presentation or try to poke holes in it. Q&A Hack: If you have a large deck you can't get through in your time limit, keep the additional slides after your conclusion slide as Appenices and refer to them as needed in your Q&A. It's okay to admit you don't know or don't have an answer. The worst mistake I saw someone make in their Q&A was to try to give a BS answer about a technical topic that was not their core competency. Don't try to smoke & mirror the judges; they will call you on your BS. Overall, this was a fun and fantastic learning experience! JK, I wasn't the keynote speaker this time . But I did give a workshop on developing your personal brand to a room full of government IT managers and professionals! Despite the fact I've spoken 35+ times before, this was my first time speaking at a conference! And I was NERVOUS . Typically, my audience is people close to my age (16-24). But this time, my entire audience was older than me, with it mostly being comprised of mid- to senior-level professionals [including a few C-suiters ]. In spite of my nervousness, I made it through, cracked a few jokes, and even taught my audience the Gen Z meaning of flex. Aside from that, my presentation was primarily focused on building a personal brand within your organization [not externally, like on LinkedIn] and how you can use it to advance your career. Here are 5 key takeaways from my presentation ~  Define your brand identity by asking yourself What are the things I want to be known for?If my colleagues could describe me in three words, what would they be?, and What are my 'superpowers?  Become a better communicator by telling stories to portray ideas and understand your audience by empathizing with your listener.  Build quality relationships by going deep instead of wide ~ basically quality > quantity. Use the 33/33/33 rule when networking, and ABPV (Always Be Providing Value).  Seek out professional development opportunities proactively and be prepared when those opportunities come knocking.  Leverage community by joining organizations and groups ~ not only will this help you find people you can build with [accountability buddies, moral support, etc], but it will also show what's important to you [i.e. Society fo Women Engineers, minority BERGs]  Big thank you to GMIS Nevada for having me and to the Atlantis Casino Resort Spa for providing a fantastic venue! In previous generations, having a 2nd job was only something someone did if they needed the money or the salary from their day job wasn't cutting it. But Gen Z is totally changing that narrative! For some Gen Zs, starting a side hustle IS motivated by need, but we have so many more reasons than just finances. My main side hustle, as you can probably guess, is content creation. I did not start creating content with the intention of making money from it. Initially, it was simply a hobby and a creative outlet. But as it grew, my content creation became so much more. It became a way for me to advance my career as a Product Manager, build a portfolio of work [that was completely unrelated to my day job ], receive unique opportunities (speaking engagements, press, etc.), and eventually, make an income. It's also a key piece of my portfolio career (a term coined by Meagan Loyst ). Like many other Gen Zs, my identity and existence aren't tied to my job, and we've figured out that one job can't fulfill us completely ~ and that's okay!! That's why we side hustle and build portfolio careers! But going back to the making money from side hustles bit, Gen Zs build side hustles for multiple reasons related to finance. We've watched our friends, colleagues, and classmates get laid off at the slightest turn of the economy, and in this day and age, job security is kind of a mythical creature; having a side hustle can alleviate some of the stress from that lack of job security. Job hunting sucks.

There's no sugar-coating it. Recently, I went through an interview process with four rounds of interviews. I seriously thought I had a good shot of getting the role. I completed my last round but hadn't heard anything for two weeks. So I followed up with the recruitment manager, asking if I needed to complete any more steps for my application. Then, I got the dreaded After careful consideration, we are moving forward with other candidates email and another generic-sounding email (though from an actual person) telling me to check my email and that you had a great background, but we're moving forward with other candidates. Words cannot describe the frustration that I feel. If I have a great background, why didn't I get the role? And did we really need to go through 4 interview rounds and 6 hours of prep time to come to that conclusion? Sure, the rejection hurts. But what frustrates me is a lack of feedback and even empathy. But I'm not just here to rant. Out of the 200+ applications and hiring processes I've been through, there were 2 in particular (both rejections), but still had a pleasant and personable hiring process. Here are 3 key takeaways from that process that I HOPE more recruiters and hiring managers will put into practice ~  Please take just 5-10 minutes to give us feedback. If you have 5 minutes left in an interview or a candidate follows up after a rejection, please take the time to provide feedback. In 2021, one recruiter took the time to give me feedback on my resume during my interview despite the fact that I got rejected for the role. She probably doesn't know this, but she might've changed my entire career trajectory with that feedback.  Provide your candidates updates and have transparency in the process. Last year, I went through a recruitment process for an internship with an amazing recruiter, and she sent me updates at least once a week, if not twice. If she didn't have an update on my application, she'd send me prep resources for the next round or offer a call to check in and see how I was doing. And as soon as she knew the next steps, she'd email me.  Don't just send the auto-reject template email if they've invested significant time into the process. I totally understand getting auto-rejection emails after submitting an initial application but after four interviews? Seriously? With the recruiter I previously mentioned, I ended up getting rejected for the role. But rather than sending a template generic email, she called me to talk it over with me, provide feedback, and offer help in the future. Because of how I was treated in these processes, I still think very highly of these companies and I would apply again in a heartbeat if the occasion arose. And yet, so many companies are dumbfounded when it comes to employer branding and what they can do to attract more talent. It's not rocket science ~ start with creating recruitment processes that don't dehumanize candidates.

I'm a senior in college, and I'm having an existential crisis.

Okay, not really. But I am pretty uncertain of what I'll do in 8 months when I graduate. It's not that I'm clueless. I've just realized that there are more opportunities out there than I previously considered, and it turns out [surprise] that I'm passionate about several different things! It's perfectly okay to not have a perfectly flushed-out roadmap for the rest of your life when you're 20-24 years old. But on the flip side of that same coin, you should try to prepare as best as you can. My favorite keyword for this ~ exploration. So, entering my senior year, here are the 5 things that I would do/do better/have done differently to be as career-ready as possible ahead of graduation: [Remember: the theme is explore, explore, explore]  Be creative with your education. You might think you know what you want to major in, but things can change. If you can, take classes outside your primary major; strive for a somewhat interdisciplinary education. I supplemented Computer science classes with business, entrepreneurship, and math classes.  Travel a little bit! You don't have to be Mr. or Mrs. Worldwide. Just get out of your little bubble and visit places you've always wanted to. Why? It's a good way to figure out if and where you want to move and continue your career after college + if that place has opportunities in your field.  Get experience at different-sized companies. Working at a startup is VASTLY different than working at a medium-sized or Fortune 100 company. I've worked at two startups, one small venture fund, and one Fortune 100. Each experience taught me something new and helped me figure out which environment I prefer.  Get experience doing different job functions. Chances are, with your field of study, you can qualify for multiple different types of jobs. For example, if you're a CS major, you could do SWE, Systems Engineering, Backend, Data Science, or Product Management. Try different roles to see what you like and what comes naturally to you. IDK how many times I have to say it, but PAY YOUR INTERNS.

I got these two job alerts in the past weekend, and I'm both confused and agitated. If a role is high priority, why is it unpaid , like please make it make sense. That being said, the reality is that we're in a time where a lot of students are desperate, and my guess is we're going to see more and more employers exploiting students' positions oh sorry, I meant to say offering unpaid internships. So, to both students/aspiring interns and college career centers, please keep these things in mind: Students who have done unpaid internships are only 1.8% more likely to land a full-time job than students who have never done internships (no internship - 35.2%, unpaid internship - 37%) [Source: The Atlantic/NACE]. As of 2022, the median starting salary for students who did paid internships was $20k higher than students who did unpaid internships [Source: State Press/NACE]. And for the students, here's what you should do, if you're contemplating an unpaid internship ~ Keep looking. I was offered an unpaid internship as a freshman, but something didn't feel right about it. So I kept looking, and I found not 1, not 2, but 5 different employers who were willing to pay me as an intern. If you're just going for the experience, take a look at micro-internships on sites like Parker Dewey. They're typically shorter commitments, but you get industry experience AND you get paid [+they're offered year-round, not just during summer]. Look into grants/programs at your school. Most institutions of higher education offer grants, stipends, etc. to students who are being offered unpaid or low-paid internships. (Ex: UNR, Pack Internship Grant Program, $16/hr for 120 hours of work). And to the employers: DO BETTER
